The brain interprets the burning of the pepper as if the tongue had been burned and causes the opioid receptors of the central nervous system to produce endorphin, responsible for the sense of well-being.

The myth that the seed of pepper is the one responsible for the ardence is spread to this day, but the great truth is that the substance that brings this "spice" to the plant is capsaicin. This substance is produced by glands located in the placenta of the fruits, that is, where the seeds are. Peppers produce this substance as a form of defense against bacteria and fungi that feed on it.
